original_data.question: A 32-year-old female complains to her gynecologist that she has had irregular periods for several years. She has severe facial acne and dense black hairs on her upper lip, beneath her hairline anterior to her ears, and the back of her neck. Ultrasound reveals bilateral enlarged ovaries with multiple cysts. Which of the following is the patient most likely increased risk of developing?

model_response:
This patient has the signs of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS), which is characterized by amenorrhea, obesity, hirsutism, and enlarged ovaries with multiple cysts. The increased conversion of androgens to estrogen in the ovarian cysts leads to endometrial hyperplasia and an increased risk of endometrial carcinoma. Addison disease is not associated with PCOS. PCOS is associated with insulin resistance, which can lead to glucose intolerance. PCOS is not associated with Wegener granulomatosis or eclampsia.

Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human females as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Qualified medical professionals who specialize in GYNECOLOGY.

The periodic shedding of the ENDOMETRIUM and associated menstrual bleeding in the MENSTRUAL CYCLE of humans and primates. Menstruation is due to the decline in circulating PROGESTERONE, and occurs at the late LUTEAL PHASE when LUTEOLYSIS of the CORPUS LUTEUM takes place.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
The anterior portion of the head that includes the skin, muscles, and structures of the forehead, eyes, nose, mouth, cheeks, and jaw.
Having high relative density or specific gravity; permitting little if any light to pass through.
Lip, each instance of which is the fleshy margin of the mouth that bounds superiorly some oral orifice.
Bona fide anatomical line delineating hair from forehead part of face.

The hearing and equilibrium system of the body. It consists of three parts: the EXTERNAL EAR, the MIDDLE EAR, and the INNER EAR. Sound waves are transmitted through this organ where vibration is transduced to nerve signals that pass through the ACOUSTIC NERVE to the CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM. The inner ear also contains the vestibular organ that maintains equilibrium by transducing signals to the VESTIBULAR NERVE.
The part of a human or animal body connecting the HEAD to the rest of the body.

The visualization of deep structures of the body by recording the reflections or echoes of ultrasonic pulses directed into the tissues. Use of ultrasound for imaging or diagnostic purposes employs frequencies ranging from 1.6 to 10 megahertz.
Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.

The reproductive organ (GONADS) in female animals. In vertebrates, the ovary contains two functional parts: the OVARIAN FOLLICLE for the production of female germ cells (OOGENESIS); and the endocrine cells (GRANULOSA CELLS; THECA CELLS; and LUTEAL CELLS) for the production of ESTROGENS and PROGESTERONE.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
The probability that an event will occur. It encompasses a variety of measures of the probability of a generally unfavorable outcome.
